summary: Winston Scott was the Chief of Station for the CIA in Mexico. A memorandum details a conversation between President Lopez Mateos of Mexico and Mr. Winston Scott, Chief of Station, Mexico, where Lopez Mateos conveyed his friendship to the United States, his invitation to President Dorticos of Cuba, and his decision not to invite Fidel Castro to Mexico. His name appears in a list of individuals connected with the CIA station in Mexico City during Lee Harvey Oswald's visit. Robert T. Shaw's testimony before the HSCA focused on CIA activities in Mexico City in 1963 related to Lee Harvey Oswald and Cuban operations.
significance: As the CIA Chief of Station in Mexico, Winston Scott was in a key position to oversee and potentially influence intelligence gathering and operations related to Lee Harvey Oswald's activities in Mexico City prior to the JFK assassination. His role places him at the center of investigations into possible CIA connections to Oswald and Cuban operations.
